description: Hamiltonian simulation—computing the time evolution of quantum many-body systems—is considered one of the most natural applications for quantum computers. Simulating quantum dynamics on classical computers requires resources that scale exponentially with system size for general Hamiltonians.
Applications include simulating condensed matter systems, understanding quantum phase transitions, modeling chemical reactions, and exploring high-energy physics phenomena.
Trotterized time evolution circuits can become very deep for long simulation times or high accuracy, making error mitigation essential for extracting meaningful results from NISQ devices.
why_qem: Simulation accuracy degrades with both circuit depth and simulation time. Error mitigation extends the regime where accurate dynamics can be extracted.
The landmark IBM 127-qubit experiment demonstrated that error-mitigated quantum simulation can reach regimes intractable for brute-force classical computation.
Probabilistic error amplification (PEA) enables precise noise scaling for ZNE without the large stretch factors required by gate folding, making it practical for utility-scale circuits.
Pauli twirling converts coherent errors into stochastic Pauli noise, which is easier to characterize and mitigate.

demonstrations.title: 127-Qubit Kicked Ising Model (IBM, 2023)
demonstrations.description: Simulated dynamics of a kicked Ising model on a 127-qubit heavy-hex lattice with 60 layers of two-qubit gates (2800+ CNOT gates). Error-mitigated results matched tensor network simulations where tractable and extended beyond classical reach.

demonstrations.title: Quantum Field Theory Simulation
demonstrations.description: Applied NOX (noiseless output extrapolation) to simulate quantum field theory dynamics, demonstrating error mitigation for physics applications.

challenges: Trotter errors from discretization add to hardware errors
Long-time dynamics require very deep circuits
Verifying results beyond classical simulability is difficult
